channel.title: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP
channel.description:
I want to make my RSPS 718 online for others to join and I dont know how? I assume I need to chainge some IP to my iPv4 Adress (hamachi) Also I dont know why construction is not working properly.
Can someone help me out?
Thanks!
*https://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php?topic=657559.280* [718/753] Rune-Evo V3.

item.title: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Oh yeah, sorry for getting off topic on your thread…

Here are rough steps to getting your server running and accessible, assuming you already have it running locally.

Port-forwarding

  1. Go into your router settings.
    1)a) You can do this by going into your browser and typing 192.168.1.1 for the URL (usually) but sometimes also 192.168.0.1
    1)b) The default login information is, username: admin, password: password, sometimes it can be variants of those, like administrator instead of admin. But if you have a Wi-Fi connection that’s protected with a password, it’s sometimes the wifi password.
  2. After you’re on your router settings go to port-forwarding.
    2)a) Sometimes a port-forwarding link is on the home page, other times you have to look for “Advanced” or equivalent.
  3. Create a new instance under port-forwarding. You should select TCP, and for port put 43594, and for local IP, put in your local IP. Your local IP can be found by going to Start > Run… > cmd > when a black box appears, type in ipconfig. Your local IP is your IPv4 address.
  4. After you have created the new entry, save everything and log out.
  5. Go to whatsmyip.org and take note of this IP. This is your EXTERNAL IP, the one that other computers use to communicate with you. Copy it down and open your client folders.
  6. In your client folders, you need to change the IP that your client connects to. This can sometimes be in client.java, GUI.java, Jframe.java, but it depends really on what revision client you have. After finding where the current IP is, replace that with your external IP, exist out of the files after saving changes, and compile your client files.

After following the steps above, just make sure your server is running, and then send your client to your friend.

What you just did: port-forwarding - That was just a quick pass on how to do it, if you wanted more in depth instructions or images, there are a few tutorials on these forums and other sites for port-forwarding.

EDIT: As for your construction problem… Construction almost never works in private servers, but create a new thread and tell us some more information other than it simple not working, that could be hundreds of reasons.

Read full topic
item.source: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP

item.source: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP

item.title: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:544210”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=663092.msg4431601#msg4431601 date=1403485580]

Don’t use Hamachi. Just portforward and use No-Ip

B00mz is right.
Here is one of the tutorial section: (stickied at the top)
https://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,342685.0.html

The part you’re talking about is the No-ip + portforwarding part.

No, B00mz is not right. You should never find yourself using No-IP. It’s absolutely pointless, just creates a middleman/extra connection.
[/quote]
Wrong, sorry mate. But there are times.
Sometimes you don’t get a static IP address from your ISP. Sometimes it’s on a weekly, or monthly renewal. That’s up to your ISP. Instead of releasing a new client everytime it switches. You could just use No-ip to forward the connection to your new IP when it updates.

What IP should you be connecting to the server with then?

This depends on the situation.
If you’re on the same network as the person, you use the local IPv4 address, usually 192.168. It’ll be the same the start of the ip you use to login to your router. If you’re on the same computer as the source, use localhost. If you’re on a different network, use the IP found on here. If your ISP gives you a dynamic IP and not a static, it’s suggested you use something like no-ip.[/quote]

An instance like this is true, but if people have static external IPs, and they use No-IP, they’re doing extra work.

@B00mz, from your VPS go to whatsmyip.org, use that IP. A lot of people think they use No-IP to mask their IP address to hide from hackers. When in reality. Start > Run > Cmd > ping noipaddress.no-ip.org and it’ll print out the real IP.

Read full topic
item.source: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP

item.title: RSPS Play together with friends on 1 server... HELP
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

b00mz1029:

On my VPS hosted server that is online for 15+ and growing players, No-Ip is what I should use correct?

Does it’s IP address change ever? If yes, then yes. If no, then no.

Read full topic

The part you’re talking about is the No-ip + portforwarding part.

No, B00mz is not right. You should never find yourself using No-IP. It’s absolutely pointless, just creates a middleman/extra connection.
[/quote]
Wrong, sorry mate. But there are times.
Sometimes you don’t get a static IP address from your ISP. Sometimes it’s on a weekly, or monthly renewal. That’s up to your ISP. Instead of releasing a new client everytime it switches. You could just use No-ip to forward the connection to your new IP when it updates.

What IP should you be connecting to the server with then?

This depends on the situation.
If you’re on the same network as the person, you use the local IPv4 address, usually 192.168. It’ll be the same the start of the ip you use to login to your router. If you’re on the same computer as the source, use localhost. If you’re on a different network, use the IP found on here. If your ISP gives you a dynamic IP and not a static, it’s suggested you use something like no-ip.[/quote]

On my VPS hosted server that is online for 15+ and growing players, No-Ip is what I should use correct?

No, B00mz is not right. You should never find yourself using No-IP. It’s absolutely pointless, just creates a middleman/extra connection.[/quote]
Wrong, sorry mate. But there are times.

b00mz1029:

This depends on the situation.
If you’re on the same network as the person, you use the local IPv4 address, usually 192.168. It’ll be the same the start of the ip you use to login to your router. If you’re on the same computer as the source, use localhost. If you’re on a different network, use the IP found on here. If your ISP gives you a dynamic IP and not a static, it’s suggested you use something like no-ip.
